sections.title: Lead

sentence_evaluations.sentence: **3-beta-glucuronosyltransferase 1** (B3GAT1) is an [enzyme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme) that in humans is encoded by the *B3GAT1* [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene), whose enzymatic activity creates the CD57 [epitope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epitope) on other cell surface proteins.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the sentence uses gene abbreviations and full names.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The gene abbreviation '*B3GAT1*' is italicized, but the full gene name '3-beta-glucuronosyltransferase 1' is bolded, not italicized.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Strong adherence with minor formatting issues; the gene abbreviation is properly italicized, but the full gene name should also be italicized to fully meet the requirement.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the sentence mentions the gene name.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: Both the full gene name and abbreviation are used.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Strong adherence; the abbreviation is used along with the full name, which is acceptable though the recommendation is to use abbreviations.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the sentence mentions human gene names.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The gene name 'B3GAT1' is written in capitals as per guidelines.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully meets the requirement by correctly capitalizing the human gene name.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because it's the lead sentence and the gene has a human ortholog.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The sentence uses the recommended UniProt name '3-beta-glucuronosyltransferase 1' and the HUGO gene symbol 'B3GAT1'.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully meets the requirement by including both the UniProt name and the HUGO gene symbol in the lead.

sentence_evaluations.meta_notes: Consider italicizing the full gene name '3-beta-glucuronosyltransferase 1' for full compliance with formatting guidelines.

sentence_evaluations.sentence: In [immunology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immunology), the CD57 [antigen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antigen) (CD stands for [cluster of differentiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_of_differentiation)) is also known as HNK1 (human natural killer-1) or LEU7.

It is expressed as a carbohydrate [epitope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epitope) that contains a sulfoglucuronyl residue in several [adhesion molecules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cell_adhesion_molecule) of the [nervous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nervous_system).

**3-beta-glucuronosyltransferase 1** (B3GAT1) is an [enzyme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme) that in humans is encoded by the *B3GAT1* [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene), whose enzymatic activity creates the CD57 [epitope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epitope) on other cell surface proteins.

sections.title: Function

sentence_evaluations.sentence: The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the glucuronyltransferase gene family.
These enzymes exhibit strict acceptor specificity, recognizing nonreducing terminal sugars and their anomeric linkages.
This gene product functions as the key enzyme in a glucuronyl transfer reaction during the biosynthesis of the carbohydrate epitope HNK-1 (human natural killer-1, also known as CD57 and LEU7).
Alternate transcriptional splice variants have been characterized.
The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the glucuronyltransferase gene family.
These enzymes exhibit strict acceptor specificity, recognizing nonreducing terminal sugars and their anomeric linkages.
This gene product functions as the key enzyme in a glucuronyl transfer reaction during the biosynthesis of the carbohydrate epitope HNK-1 (human natural killer-1, also known as CD57 and LEU7).
Alternate transcriptional splice variants have been characterized.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because it requires the Function section to describe the function of the transcribed protein.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The Function section describes the enzyme family, specificity, role in biosynthesis of HNK-1, and mentions alternate splice variants.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully meets the requirement by thoroughly describing the function of the transcribed protein in detail.

sections.meta_notes: The section is well-written and adequately covers the protein's function.

sections.title: Immunohistochemistry

sentence_evaluations.sentence: In anatomical pathology, CD57 (immunostaining) is similar to CD56 for use in differentiating [neuroendocrine tumors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroendocrine_tumor) from others.

Using [immunohistochemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immunohistochemistry), CD57 molecules can be demonstrated in around 10 to 20% of [lymphocytes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymphocyte), as well as in some [epithelial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epithelium), neural, and [chromaffin cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromaffin_cell).

Among [lymphocytes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymphocyte), CD57 positive cells are typically either [T cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T_cell) or [NK cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_killer_cell), and are most commonly found within the [germinal centers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germinal_center) of [lymph nodes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymph_node), tonsils, and the spleen.

There is an increase in the number of circulating CD57 positive cells in the blood of patients who have recently undergone organ or tissue transplants, especially of the bone marrow, and in patients with [HIV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HIV).

Increased CD57+ counts have also been reported in [rheumatoid arthritis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis) and [Felty's syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felty%27s_syndrome), among other conditions.

High levels of CD57 expression amongst circulating CD8+ T cells is associated with other markers of immune ageing (immunosenescence) and may be associated with increased cancer risk in renal transplant recipients.

[Neoplastic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplasm) CD57 positive cells are seen in conditions as varied as [large granular lymphocytic leukemia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_granular_lymphocytic_leukemia), [small-cell carcinoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small-cell_carcinoma), [thyroid carcinoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thyroid_neoplasm), and neural and [carcinoid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carcinoid_tumor) tumors.

Although the antigen is particularly common in carcinoid tumors, it is found in such a wide range of other conditions that it is of less use in distinguishing these tumors from others than more specific markers such as [chromogranin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromogranin) and [neuron-specific enolase (NSE)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuron_specific_enolase).

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the section provides details on tissue distribution of the protein.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The section describes expression of CD57 in lymphocytes, epithelial cells, neural cells, and chromaffin cells.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully meets the guideline by extensively covering the tissue distribution of CD57 positive cells.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the section lists diseases and conditions associated with changes in levels of the protein.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The section lists conditions such as organ transplant recipients, HIV, rheumatoid arthritis, Felty's syndrome, and various cancers.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully meets the requirement by listing multiple diseases related to changes in the protein expression.

sections.meta_notes: The section comprehensively covers the clinical significance and tissue distribution of CD57 positive cells.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: Applicable because the article scope includes the human gene and mentions the protein.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The lead section introduces the human gene and enzyme.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: Fully adheres to the requirement by covering the human gene/protein.
